 Ltd. qualifies as an &#x201C;emerging growth company&#x201D; pursuant to the provisions of the Jumpstart Our Business Startups Act (the &#x201C;JOBS Act&#x201D;)

 Ltd. remains an &#x201C;emerging growth company&#x201D; as defined in the JOBS Act

 2013
 Leucadia declared a pro rata dividend of all of the outstanding shares of Crimson&#x2019;s common stock in a manner that was structured to qualify as a tax-free spin-off for U.S. federal income tax purposes (the &#x201C;Distribution&#x201D;).&nbsp;&nbsp;Leucadia&#x2019;s common shareholders received one share of Crimson common stock for every ten common shares of Leucadia

 ultra premium and luxury market segments of the wine industry are intensely competitive.&nbsp;&nbsp;Crimson&#x2019;s wines compete domestically and internationally
 and premium or higher quality wines are produced in Europe
 South America
 South Africa
 Australia and New Zealand
 as well as in the United States.&nbsp;&nbsp;Crimson competes on the basis of quality
 price
 brand recognition and distribution capability
 and the ultimate consumer has many choices of products from both domestic and international producers.&nbsp;&nbsp;A result of the intense competition has been
 and may continue to be
 upward pressure on Crimson&#x2019;s selling and promotional expenses.&nbsp;&nbsp;Many of Crimson&#x2019;s competitors are significantly larger with greater financial
 production
 distribution and marketing resources.&nbsp;&nbsp;Wine production in the U.S. is dominated by three large California wineries that represent over 60% of the domestic U.S. case sales volume. Further

 Crimson will enter into agreements with brokers for those markets where it would not be cost effective to have an employee

 brokers were used by Crimson in 10 states in the U.S. and in certain export markets.&nbsp; Revenues generated through broker relationships represented approximately 12% of wine revenues during 2013.&nbsp;&nbsp;Agreements with brokers are generally terminable by either party upon notice.&nbsp;&nbsp;In the fourth quarter of 2013

 Crimson has been placing increasing emphasis on direct sales to consumers
 which it is able to do through the Internet

 and at the wineries&#x2019; tasting rooms.&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2013
 direct sales to consumers represented 12% of case sales and 38% of wine revenues.&nbsp;&nbsp;Approximately 61% of the direct to consumer sales were through wine clubs
 27% were through the wineries&#x2019; tasting rooms and the balance from the Internet
 outbound calling
 and offers through e-commerce.&nbsp;&nbsp;Members typically join our wine clubs after visiting our tasting rooms at our various facilities
 or after hearing about our wine clubs from other members.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our tasting rooms are located in vacation areas that typically attract consumers interested in wine making and touring the area.&nbsp;&nbsp;Direct sales to consumers are more profitable for Crimson as it is able to sell its products at a price closer to retail prices rather than the wholesale price received from distributors

Various diseases
 pests
 fungi
 viruses
 drought
 frosts and certain other weather conditions could affect the quality and quantity of grapes
 decreasing the supply of our products and negatively impacting our operating results.&nbsp;&nbsp;Future government restrictions regarding the use of certain materials used in grape growing may increase vineyard costs and/or reduce production.&nbsp;&nbsp;We cannot guarantee that our grape suppliers will succeed in preventing disease in their existing vineyards or that we will succeed in preventing disease in our existing vineyards or future vineyards we may acquire.&nbsp;&nbsp;For instance
 Pierce&#x2019;s disease is a vine bacterial disease which kills grapevines and there is no known cure.&nbsp;&nbsp;Small insects called sharpshooters spread this disease.&nbsp;&nbsp;A new strain of the sharpshooter was discovered in Southern California and is believed to be migrating north.&nbsp;&nbsp;If our vineyards become contaminated with this or other diseases

The wine industry is intensely competitive and highly fragmented.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our wines compete in several wine market segments with many other domestic and foreign wines.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our wines also compete with popular priced generic wines and with other alcoholic and
 to a lesser degree
 non-alcoholic beverages.&nbsp;&nbsp;A result of this intense competition has been and may continue to be upward pressure on our selling and promotional expenses.&nbsp;&nbsp;Many of our competitors have greater financial
 technical

		

			
		


 Nationwide we sell our products primarily through independent distributors and brokers for resale to retail outlets
 restaurants
 hotels and private clubs across the U.S. and in some overseas markets.&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales to distributors are expected to continue to represent a substantial portion of our net revenues in the future.&nbsp;&nbsp;A change in our relationship with any of our significant distributors could harm our business and reduce our sales.&nbsp;&nbsp;The laws and regulations of several states prohibit changes of distributors
 except under certain limited circumstances
 making it difficult to terminate a distributor for poor performance without reasonable cause
 as defined by applicable statutes.&nbsp;&nbsp;Any difficulty or inability to replace distributors
 poor performance of our major distributors or our inability to collect accounts receivable from our major distributors could harm our business.&nbsp;&nbsp;There can be no assurance that the distributors and retailers we use will continue to purchase our products or provide our products with adequate levels of promotional support.&nbsp;&nbsp;Consolidation at the retail tier
 among club and chain grocery stores in particular

		

			
		

We are subject to certain hazards and product liability risks

		
		

			
		

			&nbsp;
		

contamination
 through tampering or otherwise
 of ingredients or products.&nbsp;&nbsp;Contamination of any of our wines could cause us to destroy our wine held in inventory and could cause the need for a product recall
 which could significantly damage our reputation for product quality.&nbsp;&nbsp;We maintain insurance against certain of these kinds of risks
 and others
 under various insurance policies.&nbsp;&nbsp;However

		

			
		

There have been periods in the past in which there were substantial declines in the overall per capita consumption of wine products in our markets.&nbsp;&nbsp;A limited or general decline in consumption in one or more of our product categories could occur in the future due to a variety of factors
 including: a general decline in economic conditions; changes in consumer spending habits; increased concern about the health consequences of consuming alcoholic beverage products and about drinking and driving; a trend toward a healthier diet including lighter
 lower calorie beverages such as diet soft drinks
 juices and water products; the increased activity of anti-alcohol consumer groups; and increased federal

		

			
		

 Many of Crimson&#x2019;s brands are issued ratings or scores by local and national wine rating organizations
 and higher scores usually translate into greater demand and higher pricing.&nbsp;&nbsp;Although some of Crimson&#x2019;s brands have been highly rated in the past
 and Crimson believes its farming and winemaking activities are of a quality to generate good ratings in the future

		

			
		


 or legal
 regulatory or market measures to address climate change
 may negatively affect our business
 operations or financial performance
 Our business depends upon agricultural activity and natural resources
 including the availability of water.&nbsp;&nbsp;There has been much public discussion related to concerns that carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases in the atmosphere may have an adverse impact on global temperatures
 weather patterns and the frequency and severity of extreme weather and natural disasters.&nbsp;&nbsp;Severe weather events and climate change may negatively affect agricultural productivity in our vineyards.&nbsp;&nbsp;The quality and quantity of water available for use is important to the supply of grapes and our ability to operate our business.&nbsp;&nbsp;Adverse weather
 measures enacted to address climate change

		

			
		

We are subject to environmental regulations with respect to our operations
 including those related to wastewater
 air emissions
 and hazardous materials use
 storage and disposal.&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition
 we own substantial amounts of real property that are critical to our business.&nbsp;&nbsp;If hazardous substances are discovered on any of our properties and the concentrations are such that the presence of such hazardous substances presents an unreasonable risk of harm to public health or the environment
 we may be held strictly liable for the cost of investigation and remediation of hazardous substances.&nbsp;&nbsp;The cost of environmental remediation could be significant and adversely impact our financial condition

		

			
		

In March 2013
 we entered into a revolving credit facility with American AgCredit
 FLCA and CoBank
 FCB as joint lenders that is secured by substantially all of our assets.&nbsp;&nbsp;We plan to rely upon the revolving credit facility for potential incremental capital project funding and in the future may use it for acquisitions.&nbsp;&nbsp;No amounts are currently outstanding.&nbsp;&nbsp;The revolving credit facility includes covenants that require the maintenance of specified debt and equity ratios
 limit the incurrence of additional indebtedness
 limit dividends and other distributions to shareholders and limit certain mergers
 consolidations and sales of assets.&nbsp;&nbsp;If we are unable to comply with these covenants

		

			
		

 Government laws and regulations result in increased farming costs
 and the sale of wine is subject to taxation in various state
 federal and foreign jurisdictions.&nbsp;&nbsp;The amount of wine that we can sell directly to consumers outside of California is regulated
 and in certain states we are not allowed to sell wines directly to consumers and/or the amount that can be sold is limited.&nbsp;&nbsp;Changes in these laws and regulations could have an adverse impact on sales and/or increase costs to produce and/or sell wine.&nbsp;&nbsp;The wine industry is subject to extensive regulation by the &#x201C;TTB&#x201D; and various foreign agencies
 state liquor authorities
 such as the &#x201C;CABC&#x201D;
 and local authorities.&nbsp;&nbsp;These regulations and laws dictate such matters as licensing requirements
 trade and pricing practices
 permitted distribution channels
 permitted and required labeling
 and advertising and relations with wholesalers and retailers.&nbsp;&nbsp;Any expansion of our existing facilities or development of new vineyards or wineries may be limited by present and future zoning ordinances
 environmental restrictions and other legal requirements.&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition
 new regulations or requirements or increases in excise taxes
 income taxes
 property and sales taxes or international tariffs
 could affect our financial condition or results of operations.&nbsp;&nbsp;Recently
 many states have considered proposals to increase
 and some of these states have increased
 state alcohol excise taxes.&nbsp;&nbsp;New or revised regulations or increased licensing fees
 requirements or taxes could have a material adverse effect on our financial condition

 for which we may be unable to accurately assess our level of exposure and which if adversely determined

 if our assessment proves to be in error

		

			
		

			
		

			
		


We have substantial intangible assets and goodwill on our balance sheet as a result of acquisitions we have completed
 in particular the acquisition of Seghesio Family Vineyards.&nbsp;&nbsp;We review intangible assets and goodwill for impairment annually or more frequently if events or circumstances indicate that these assets might be impaired.&nbsp;&nbsp;Application of impairment tests requires judgment.&nbsp;&nbsp;A significant deterioration in a key estimate or assumption or a less significant deterioration to a combination of assumptions or the sale of a part of a reporting unit could result in an impairment charge in the future

		

			
		

 &nbsp;&nbsp;Prices for our common stock are quoted on the Over-The-Counter (OTC) Market.&nbsp;&nbsp;Securities whose prices are quoted on the OTC Market do not have the same liquidity as securities that trade on a recognized market or securities exchange.&nbsp;&nbsp;An active trading market for our common stock may not be sustained in the future.&nbsp;&nbsp;As a result

		

			
		

The stock market has from time to time experienced extreme price and volume fluctuations that often have been unrelated to the operating performance of particular companies.&nbsp;&nbsp;Changes in earnings estimates by analysts
 if any

		

			
		

The market price of our common stock could decline as a result of sales of a large number of shares of our common stock in the market or the perception that these sales could occur.&nbsp;&nbsp;These sales
 or the possibility that these sales may occur
 also might make it more difficult for us to sell equity securities in the future at a time and at a price that we deem appropriate.&nbsp;&nbsp;Any disposition by any of our large shareholders of our common stock in the public market
 or the perception that such dispositions could occur

		

			
		

 Changing laws
 regulations and standards relating to corporate governance and public disclosure
 including the Sarbanes-Oxley Act and the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act
 are creating uncertainty for companies such as ours.&nbsp;&nbsp;We are committed to maintaining appropriate corporate governance and public disclosure.&nbsp;&nbsp;As a result
 we may see an increase in general and administrative expenses and a diversion of management time and attention from revenue-generating activities to compliance activities

		

			
		

 We are an &#x201C;emerging growth company
&#x201D; as defined in the Jumpstart Our Business Startups Act (the &#x201C;JOBS Act&#x201D;) and have taken advantage of certain exemptions from various reporting requirements that are applicable to other public companies that are not emerging growth companies
 including
 but not limited to
 not being required to comply with the auditor attestation requirements of Section 404(b) of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act
 reduced disclosure obligations regarding executive compensation in our periodic reports and proxy statements
 and exemptions from the requirement of holding a nonbinding stockholder advisory vote on executive compensation
 frequency of approval of executive compensation and any golden parachute payments not previously approved.&nbsp;&nbsp;We will retain emerging growth company status until the earliest of:&nbsp;&nbsp;(1) the last day of the fiscal year following the fifth anniversary of the date we first sold securities pursuant to an effective registration statement under the Securities Act; (2) the last day of the fiscal year in which we first had total annual gross revenues of $1 billion or more (indexed pursuant to the JOBS Act); (3) the date on which we are deemed to be a &#x201C;large accelerated filer&#x201D; as defined in Exchange Act Rule 12b-2 (i.e.
 an SEC registered company with a public float of at least $700 million that satisfies other tests); or (4) the date on which we have
 within the previous three years
 issued more than $1 billion of nonconvertible debt.&nbsp;&nbsp;Under the JOBS Act
 emerging growth companies can delay adopting new or revised accounting standards until such time as those standards apply to private companies.&nbsp;&nbsp;However
 we have irrevocably elected not to avail ourselves of this extended transition period for complying with new or revised accounting standards and
 therefore

		

			
		


 we cannot predict if investors will find our common stock less attractive because we rely on these exemptions.&nbsp;&nbsp;If some investors find our common stock less attractive as a result of our reduced disclosures

 which have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the U.S. (&#x201C;GAAP&#x201D;).&nbsp;&nbsp;The preparation of these financial statements requires Crimson to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts in the financial statements and disclosures of contingent assets and liabilities.&nbsp;&nbsp;On an on-going basis
 Crimson evaluates all of these estimates and assumptions.&nbsp;&nbsp;The following areas have been identified as critical accounting estimates because they have the potential to have a significant impact on Crimson&#x2019;s financial statements
 and because they are based on assumptions that are used in the accounting records to reflect
 at a specific point in time

		

			
		

&#x2014;Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market
 with cost being determined on the first-in
 first-out method.&nbsp;&nbsp;Costs associated with winemaking
 and other costs associated with the manufacturing of products for resale
 are recorded as inventory.&nbsp;&nbsp;In accordance with general practice within the wine industry
 wine inventories are included in current assets
 although a portion of such inventories may be aged for periods longer than one year.&nbsp;&nbsp;As required

		
		

			
		

			&nbsp;
		

obsolete or in excess of estimated usage to estimated net realizable value.&nbsp;&nbsp;Crimson&#x2019;s estimates of net realizable value are based on analyses and assumptions including
 but not limited to
 historical usage
 future demand and market requirements.&nbsp;&nbsp;Reductions to the carrying value of inventories are recorded in cost of sales.&nbsp;&nbsp;If future demand and/or pricing for Crimson&#x2019;s products are less than previously estimated
 then the carrying value of the inventories may be required to be reduced
 resulting in additional expense and reduced profitability.&nbsp;&nbsp;Inventory write-downs 
 $50
000 and $51
000 were recorded during 2013
 2012 and 2011

		

			
		

&#x2014;Crimson capitalizes internal vineyard development costs when developing new vineyards or replacing or improving existing vineyards.&nbsp;&nbsp;These costs consist primarily of the costs of the vines and expenditures related to labor and materials to prepare the land and construct vine trellises.&nbsp;&nbsp;Amortization of such costs as annual crop costs is recorded on a straight-line basis over the estimated economic useful life of the vineyard
 which can be as long as 25 years.&nbsp;&nbsp;As circumstances warrant
 Crimson re-evaluates the recoverability of capitalized costs

		

			
		

&#x2014;For intangible assets with definite lives
 impairment testing is required if conditions exist that indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable.&nbsp;&nbsp;For intangible assets with indefinite lives and for goodwill
 impairment testing is required at least annually or more frequently if events or circumstances indicate that these assets might be impaired.&nbsp;&nbsp;Crimson currently has no intangible assets with indefinite lives.&nbsp;&nbsp;Substantially all of Crimson&#x2019;s goodwill and other intangible assets result from the acquisition of Seghesio Family Vineyards in May 2011.&nbsp;&nbsp;Amortization of intangible assets is recorded on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of the assets
 which range from 7 to 17 years.&nbsp;&nbsp;Crimson evaluates goodwill for impairment at the end of each year

		

			
		


 which could be caused by general economic or other factors
 changes in laws or regulations that make it difficult or more costly for the Company to distribute its products to its markets at prices which generate adequate returns
 natural disasters

		

			
		



		

			
		



		

			
		

&#x2014;Crimson pays depletion allowances to its distributors based on their sales to their customers.&nbsp;&nbsp;These allowances are estimated on a monthly basis by Crimson
 and allowances are accrued as a reduction of revenues.&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequently
 distributors will bill Crimson for actual depletions

 Crimson has also been placing increased emphasis on generating revenue from direct sales to consumers which occur through wine clubs
 at the wineries&#x2019; tasting rooms and through the internet and direct outreach to customers.&nbsp;&nbsp;Direct sales to consumers are more profitable for Crimson as it is able to sell its products at a price closer to retail prices rather than the wholesale price received from distributors.&nbsp;&nbsp;From time to time Crimson may sell grapes or bulk wine
 because the wine does not meet the quality standards for Crimson&#x2019;s products

 Crimson has been included in the consolidated federal income tax return of Leucadia and filed a California state income tax separate from Leucadia. Prior to 2013
 Crimson had not recorded a federal or state income tax benefit for its pre-tax losses
 as sufficient evidence did not exist to enable Crimson to conclude that it is more likely than not that it can generate sufficient taxable income in the future to realize such benefits.&nbsp;&nbsp;As a result
 Crimson recorded a full valuation allowance against its net deferred tax asset
 which is the primary reason for the difference between the effective income tax rate and the federal statutory rate for 2012 and 2011.&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December 31
 2013
 the Company determined it is more likely than not that a portion of the benefit will be realized
deferred tax asset of $2
500
.&nbsp;&nbsp;For the year ended December 31

 for California and Oregon state income tax.&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior to 2012

 Crimson has a revolving credit facility

 age 46.&nbsp;&nbsp;Mr. Cumming was elected as a director in February 2013.&nbsp;&nbsp;Mr. Cumming has been the Chairman

 we are not subject to listing standards that would require us to have a compensation committee or that would require director nominees to be selected or recommended by a majority of independent directors or a nominating committee comprised solely of independent directors.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Board believes it is appropriate to have all directors involved in setting executive and director compensation and in the process of nominating directors
 rather than delegate these responsibilities to a smaller group of directors.&nbsp;&nbsp;As indicated below
 under the listing standards of the NASDAQ Stock Market
 Messrs. Carlson

		

			
		

			
		

			
		


 with respect to an election to be held at an annual meeting of stockholders
 no earlier than 150 days and no later than 120 days before the first anniversary of our proxy statement in connection with the last annual meeting
 and
 with respect to an election to be held at a special meeting of stockholders
 no earlier than 150 days before such special meeting and no later than 120 days before such special meeting
 or if the first public notice of such special meeting is less than 130 days prior to the date of such special meeting
 the tenth day following the date on which public notice of the meeting is first given to stockholders.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The notice shall provide such information as required under the Company&#x2019;s By-laws
 including
 without limitation
 the name and address of the stockholder and his or her nominees
 a representation that the stockholder is entitled to vote at the meeting and intends to nominate the person
 a description of all arrangements or understandings between the stockholder and each nominee
 other information as would be required to be included in a proxy statement soliciting proxies for the election of the stockholder&#x2019;s nominees
 the consent of each nominee to serve as a director of the Company if so elected
 information concerning the stockholder&#x2019;s direct and indirect ownership of securities of the Company
 including with respect to any beneficial owner of securities of the Company held by the stockholder

 the Board of Directors will consider making incentive compensation awards that are purely discretionary

 our Board of Directors adopted an equity compensation plan
 which allows the Company to grant incentive stock options
 nonqualified stock options
 stock appreciation rights
 restricted stock
 and other stock-based awards
 and performance-based compensation awards to its officers
 employees
 and non-employee directors.&nbsp;&nbsp;The equity compensation plan will be administered by our Board of Directors
 which is authorized to select the officers
 employees and non-employee directors to whom awards will be granted
 and to determine the type and amount of such awards.&nbsp;&nbsp;The maximum number of shares available for issuance under the plan is 1 million.&nbsp;&nbsp;To the extent permitted by Section 162(m) of the Code
 our Board of Directors is authorized to design any award so that the amounts or shares payable or distributed pursuant to such award will be treated as &#x201C;qualified performance-based compensation&#x201D; within the meaning of Section 162(m) of the Code and related regulations.&nbsp;&nbsp;The equity compensation plan was filed as an Exhibit to the Company&#x2019;s Form 8K
 filed on February 1
 2013.&nbsp;&nbsp;This summary of the plan is qualified in its entirety by reference to the full text of the plan.&nbsp;&nbsp;As of the date of this report

 our common stock is subject to transfer restrictions that are designed to reduce the possibility that certain changes in ownership could result in limitations on the use of our tax attributes.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our certificate of incorporation contains provisions that generally restrict the ability of a person or entity from acquiring ownership (including through attribution under the tax law) of 5% or more of our common shares and the ability of persons or entities now owning 5% or more of our common shares from acquiring additional common shares.&nbsp;&nbsp;Stockholders (and prospective stockholders) are advised that
 under the tax law rules incorporated in these provisions
 the acquisition of even a single share of common stock may be proscribed under our certificate of incorporation
 given (among other things) the tax law ownership attribution rules as well as the tax law rules applicable to acquisitions made in coordination with or in concert with others.&nbsp;&nbsp;The restriction will remain until the earliest of (a) December 31
 2022

 Related Persons must disclose to the Audit Committee any potential Related Person Transactions and must disclose all material facts with respect to such transaction.&nbsp;&nbsp;All Related Person Transactions will be reviewed by the Audit Committee and
 in its discretion
 approved or ratified.&nbsp;&nbsp;In determining whether to approve or ratify a Related Person Transaction the Audit Committee will consider the relevant facts and circumstances of the Related Person Transaction
 which may include factors such as the relationship of the Related Person with the Company
 the materiality or significance of the transaction to the Company and the Related Person
 the business purpose and reasonableness of the transaction
 whether the transaction is comparable to a transaction that could be available to the Company on an arms-length basis

 the Board of Directors adopted a policy for pre-approval by the Audit Committee of all audit and non-audit work performed by the Company&#x2019;s independent registered public accounting firm
 Moss Adams LLP
 and has pre-approved (i) certain general categories of work where no specific case-by-case approval is necessary (&#x201C;general pre-approvals&#x201D;) and (ii) categories of work which require the specific pre-approval of the Audit Committee (&#x201C;specific pre-approvals&#x201D;).&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional services or services in an amount above the annual amount that has been pre-approved
 additional authorization from the Audit Committee is required.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Audit Committee has delegated to Chairman of the Audit Committee the ability to pre-approve all of these services in the absence of the full committee.&nbsp;&nbsp;Any pre-approval decisions made by the Chairman of the Audit Committee under this delegated authority will be reported to the full Audit Committee.&nbsp;&nbsp;All requests for services to be provided by Moss Adams LLP that do not require specific approval by the Audit Committee must be submitted to the Chief Financial Officer of the Company
 who determines whether such services are in fact within the scope of those services that have received the general pre-approval of the Audit Committee.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Chief Financial Officer reports to the Audit Committee periodically

		

			
		

			
		

			
		


 Audit Fees are fees paid to Moss Adams LLP for professional services for the audit of the Company&#x2019;s consolidated financial statements included in the Company&#x2019;s Form 10-K
 the review of financial statements included in the Company&#x2019;s Form 10-Qs
 services that are normally provided in connection with statutory and regulatory filings or engagements
 assurance and related services that are reasonably related to the performance of the audit or review of our financial statements and 401k plan including compliance with regulatory matters

 2013
 Crimson was a wholly-owned subsidiary of Leucadia National Corporation (&#x201C;Leucadia&#x201D;).&nbsp;&nbsp;On February 1

 the production and sale of premium

 respectively).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Crimson is headquartered in Napa
 California and through its wholly-owned subsidiaries owns four wineries: Pine Ridge Vineyards
 Archery Summit
 Chamisal Vineyards and Seghesio Family Vineyards.&nbsp;&nbsp;Pine Ridge was acquired in 1991 and has been conducting operations since 1978
 Crimson started Archery Summit in 1993
 Chamisal Vineyards was acquired in 2008 and has been conducting operations since 1973
 and Seghesio Family Vineyards was acquired in 2011 and has been conducting operations since 1895.&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally
 in 2005 and 2006 Double Canyon Vineyards
 a wholly owned subsidiary

Critical Accounting Estimates: The Company&#x2019;s consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States (&#x201C;GAAP&#x201D;).&nbsp;&nbsp;The preparation of these financial statements requires the Company to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts in the financial statements and disclosures of contingent assets and liabilities.&nbsp;&nbsp;On an on-going basis
 the Company evaluates all of these estimates and assumptions.&nbsp;&nbsp;The following areas have been identified as critical accounting estimates because they have the potential to have a significant impact on the Company's financial statements
 and because they are based on assumptions which are used in the accounting records to reflect
 at a specific point in time

		

			
		

 Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market
 with cost being determined on the first-in

		
		

			
		

			&nbsp;
		

associated with winemaking
 and other costs associated with the manufacturing of products for resale
 are recorded as inventory.&nbsp;&nbsp;In accordance with general practice within the wine industry
 wine inventories are included in current assets
 although a portion of such inventories may be aged for periods longer than one year.&nbsp;&nbsp;As required
 the Company reduces the carrying value of inventories that are obsolete or in excess of estimated usage to estimated net realizable value.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#x2019;s estimates of net realizable value are based on analyses and assumptions including
 but not limited to
 historical usage
 future demand and market requirements.&nbsp;&nbsp;Reductions to the carrying value of inventories are recorded in cost of sales.&nbsp;&nbsp;If future demand and/or pricing for the Company&#x2019;s products are less than previously estimated
 then the carrying value of the inventories may be required to be reduced
 resulting in additional expense and reduced profitability.&nbsp;&nbsp;Inventory write-downs of $0
 $50
000 and $51
000 were recorded during 2013
 2012 and 2011

		

			
		

 &#x2013; The Company capitalizes internal vineyard development costs when developing new vineyards or replacing or improving existing vineyards.&nbsp;&nbsp;These costs consist primarily of the costs of the vines and expenditures related to labor and materials to prepare the land and construct vine trellises.&nbsp;&nbsp;Amortization of such costs as annual crop costs is recorded on a straight-line basis over the estimated economic useful life of the vineyard
 years.&nbsp;&nbsp;As circumstances warrant
 the Company re-evaluates the recoverability of capitalized costs
 and will record impairment charges if required.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has not recorded any significant impairment charges for its vineyards during the last 
		

			
		

 - For intangible assets with definite lives
 impairment testing is required if conditions exist that indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable.&nbsp;&nbsp;For intangible assets with indefinite lives and for goodwill
 impairment testing is required at least annually or more frequently if events or circumstances indicate that these assets might be impaired.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company currently has no intangible assets with indefinite lives.&nbsp;&nbsp;Substantially all of the Company&#x2019;s goodwill and other intangible assets result from the acquisition of Seghesio Family Vineyards in May 2011.&nbsp;&nbsp;Amortization of intangible assets is recorded on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of the assets
 years.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company evaluates goodwill for impairment at the end of each year

		

			
		


 which could be caused by general economic or other factors
 changes in laws or regulations that make it difficult or more costly for the Company to distribute its products to its markets at prices which generate adequate returns
 natural disasters

		

			
		


 the impairment to be recognized is measured by the amount by which the carrying amount of the assets exceeds the fair value of the assets.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company groups its long-lived assets with other assets and liabilities at the lowest level for which identifiable cash flows are largely independent of the cash flows of other assets and liabilities (or asset group).&nbsp;&nbsp;This would typically be at the winery level which is described in note 2 above.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company did not recognize any impairment charges associated with long-lived assets during the three year period ended December 31

		

			
		

 The Company pays depletion allowances to its distributors based on their sales to their customers.&nbsp;&nbsp;These allowances are estimated on a monthly basis by the Company
 and allowances are accrued as a reduction of sales.&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequently
 distributors will bill the Company for actual depletions

		

			
		

Consolidation policy:&nbsp;&nbsp;The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its subsidiaries

 which have maturities of less than three months at the time of acquisition
 to be cash equivalents.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company had no short-term investments at December 31

 wine clubs and the Internet is recognized when the product is received by the customer and payment is received
 based on published retail prices and applicable published discounts.&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenue includes any shipping and handling costs billed to the customer

Income taxes:&nbsp;&nbsp;Income taxes are accounted for under the asset and liability method
 which requires the recognition of deferred tax assets and liabilities for the expected future tax consequences of events that have been included in the consolidated financial statements.&nbsp;&nbsp;Under this method

		

			
		


 the Company considers all available positive and negative evidence
 including scheduled reversals of deferred tax liabilities
 projected future taxable income
 tax planning strategies and recent financial results of operations.&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior to 2013

 2013
 the Company determined it is more likely than not that a portion of the deferred tax asset will be realized in the future

Recent accounting pronouncements:&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective January 1
 2012
 the Company adopted new Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#x201C;FASB&#x201D;) guidance with respect to the improvement of the comparability of fair value measurements presented and disclosed in financial statements issued in accordance with GAAP and International Financial Reporting Standards.&nbsp;&nbsp;The amendment includes requirements for measuring fair value and for disclosing information about fair value measurements

		

			
		


 2013
 the Company adopted amended Financial Accounting Standards Board guidance for indefinite lived intangible asset impairment testing. The amended guidance allows an entity to assess qualitative factors to determine whether the existence of events and circumstances indicate that it is more likely than not that an indefinite lived intangible asset is impaired. If an entity concludes it is not more likely than not that an indefinite lived intangible asset is impaired
 the entity is not required to take further action. If an entity concludes otherwise
 then the entity would be required to determine the fair value of the indefinite lived intangible asset and compare the fair value with the carrying amount of the indefinite lived intangible asset. The Company was required to adopt this amended guidance for its annual and interim periods beginning January 1

 which occurred February 1
 2013 with the shares being distributed February 25
 2013
 the Company and its subsidiaries were included in the consolidated federal and certain consolidated or combined state income tax returns of Leucadia.&nbsp;&nbsp;However
 determined on a theoretical separate-return basis.&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to the Company&#x2019;s history of pre-tax losses
 as of the Distribution date the Company did not reflect a benefit for its net operating loss carryforwards (&#x201C;NOLs&#x201D;) since the Company was unable to conclude it was more likely than not that it would have been able to generate future taxable income to use the NOLs.&nbsp;&nbsp;As noted in Note 3
 as of December 31
 2013 the Company determined that it was more likely than not that some of the tax benefit related to the deferred tax assets would be realized and reduced the valuation allowance.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company filed a California state income tax return separate from Leucadia.&nbsp;&nbsp;The statute of limitations with respect to the Company&#x2019;s California state tax return has expired for all years through 2008.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company currently has no unrecognized tax benefits
 and it is not reasonably possible to estimate the amount by which that could increase in the next twelve months since the timing of examinations
 if any

		

			
		


 no formal tax sharing agreement was entered into between the Company and Leucadia.&nbsp;&nbsp;On the Distribution date
 the Company and Leucadia entered into a tax matters agreement that governs the parties&#x2019; respective rights

		
		

			
		

			&nbsp;
		

obligations with respect to tax liabilities and benefits
 tax attributes
 the preparation and filing of tax returns
 the control of audits and other tax proceedings and other matters regarding taxes.&nbsp;&nbsp;In general
 with respect to any periods ending at or prior to the Distribution
 Leucadia will be responsible for any federal income tax liabilities and any state or local income taxes reportable on a consolidated
 combined or unitary return
 in each case
 as would be applicable to the Company as if it filed tax returns on a stand-alone basis.&nbsp;&nbsp;With respect to any periods beginning after the Distribution
 the Company will be responsible for any federal
 state or local income taxes of it or any of its subsidiaries.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company will not be required to reimburse Leucadia for any payments made by Leucadia for adjustments to taxable periods prior to the Distribution

 to ensure that material information relating to the registrant
 including its consolidated subsidiaries
 is made known to us by others within those entities
 particularly during the period in which this report is being prepared; 

			
		
		

				
			
		


 or caused such internal control over financial reporting to be designed under our supervision
 to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles;

		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Allocation of expenses: For the years ended December 31
 2013
 2012 and 2011
 the consolidated financial statements include amounts billed/(credited) by Leucadia for general corporate insurance of &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;($85
000)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;
 &amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$305
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; and &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$335
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;
 respectively
 and for internal audit procedures related to Leucadia&amp;#x2019;s consolidated audit of internal controls over financial reporting of &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$28
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;
 &amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$13
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; and &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$38
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;
 respectively.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Amounts billed for insurance were determined either by the Company&amp;#x2019;s directly determined share of third-party insurance premiums or
 if an allocation of third-party insurance premiums
 based on the Company&amp;#x2019;s relative revenues and assets as compared to Leucadia&amp;#x2019;s consolidated revenues and consolidated assets.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Costs related to internal audit services were based on actual hours spent and the internal auditors&amp;#x2019; employment and travel costs.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Subsequent to the Distribution
 the Company became responsible for obtaining its own general corporate insurance policies and internal audit services
 which resulted in additional expense as a result of standalone policies and requirements. &lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:8pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;The Company incurred certain new and incremental costs as a standalone public company including director fees and expenses for its new board of directors
 standalone Delaware franchise tax
 standalone insurance policies increased legal and accounting fees for reviews for the Company&amp;#x2019;s publicly filed financial statements
 proxy and other filings and other services.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Such costs totaled approximately &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$1
600
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;during 2013 and the Company estimates these costs to be approximately &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$1
000
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; per year in future years.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;In addition
 the Company entered into an Administrative Services Agreement with Leucadia whereby Leucadia or its subsidiaries was to provide services principally related to the Company&amp;#x2019;s public filings and financial analysis.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The charges for the administrative services was &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$180
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;per year
 and allowed Leucadia to fully recover the costs directly associated with providing the services
 plus out-of-pocket costs and expenses.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Effective August 1
 2013
 Leucadia and the Company agreed to amend the administrative services agreement to reduce the administrative services provided to the Company by Leucadia and correspondingly reduce the monthly fee from &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$15
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; to &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$4
500&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company began to provide the administrative services that were no longer provided to the Company by Leucadia.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Pursuant to the amendment
 the administrative services agreement terminated in full in February 2014. &lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p&gt;&lt;font size=1&gt; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  

		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-style:italic;&gt;Vineyard Development Costs&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; &amp;#x2013; The Company capitalizes internal vineyard development costs when developing new vineyards or replacing or improving existing vineyards.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;These costs consist primarily of the costs of the vines and expenditures related to labor and materials to prepare the land and construct vine trellises.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Amortization of such costs as annual crop costs is recorded on a straight-line basis over the estimated economic useful life of the vineyard
 which can be as long as &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;25&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; years.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;As circumstances warrant
 the Company re-evaluates the recoverability of capitalized costs
 and will record impairment charges if required.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company has not recorded any significant impairment charges for its vineyards during the last &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;three&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; years.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p&gt;&lt;font size=1&gt; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  

		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Taxes not on income:&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Excise taxes are levied by government agencies on the sale of alcoholic beverages
 including wine.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;These taxes are not collected from customers but are instead the responsibility of the Company.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Excise taxes of &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$982
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;
 &amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$836
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; and &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$760
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; in 2013
 2012 and 2011
 respectively
 were recognized as a reduction to wine sales.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Sales taxes that are collected from customers and remitted to governmental agencies are not reflected as revenues.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p&gt;&lt;font size=1&gt; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Reductions to the carrying value of inventories to estimated net realizable value are reflected in the inventory write-down category of gross profit in the table above.&lt;/font&gt;

		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Advertising costs:&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Advertising costs are expensed as incurred and were &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$286
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;
 &amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$81
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; and &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$82
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; for the years ended December&amp;nbsp;31
 2013
 2012 and 2011
 respectively.&lt;/font&gt;

				&lt;td colspan=2 valign=bottom style=width:00.02%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt solid #000000 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #auto;height:66.75pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:center;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Quoted Prices in Active Markets for Identical Assets&lt;/font&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;(Level 1)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

				&lt;td valign=bottom style=width:01.62%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:12.75pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:right;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;overflow: hidden;font-size:0pt;&gt;
						&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
				&lt;td valign=bottom style=width:01.62%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:12.75pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:right;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
				&lt;td valign=bottom style=width:12.18%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:12.75pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt 3.25pt 0pt 0pt;text-align:right;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; -&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
			&lt;/tr&gt;
		&lt;/table&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p&gt;&lt;font size=1&gt; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;


		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Critical Accounting Estimates: The Company&amp;#x2019;s consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States (&amp;#x201C;GAAP&amp;#x201D;).&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The preparation of these financial statements requires the Company to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts in the financial statements and disclosures of contingent assets and liabilities.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;On an on-going basis
 the Company evaluates all of these estimates and assumptions.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The following areas have been identified as critical accounting estimates because they have the potential to have a significant impact on the Company's financial statements
 and because they are based on assumptions which are used in the accounting records to reflect
 at a specific point in time
 events whose ultimate outcome won&amp;#x2019;t be known until a later date.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Actual results could differ from these estimates.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p&gt;&lt;font size=1&gt; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

  
  
  
  
  
  
  

		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;font-size:1pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;div style=width:100%&gt;&lt;table cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 style=border-collapse:collapse;margin-left:0pt;&gt;
			&lt;tr&gt;
				&lt;td valign=top style=width:18.00pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:1.00pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;height:1.00pt;overflow:hidden;font-size:0pt;&gt;

					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;4.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

						&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Acquisitions:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
			&lt;/tr&gt;
		&lt;/table&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;On May 31
 2011
 a subsidiary of the Company acquired all of the assets and operations of Seghesio Winery
 Inc.
 Seghesio Farms
 Inc. and the Chianti Station Parcel (collectively
 &amp;#x201C;Seghesio Family Vineyards&amp;#x201D;).&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;This acquisition provided an opportunity to expand operations in the Sonoma County region.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;The cash purchase price was &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$86
018
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;. The acquisition was financed by a &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$41
156
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; capital contribution (including funds for expenses) and a &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$45
000
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; note payable from Leucadia.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;

018&amp;nbsp;

				&lt;td valign=bottom style=width:05.35pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #FFFFFF;height:12.40pt;padding:0pt;&gt;

		&lt;/table&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;The methods used by the Company&amp;#x2019;s management to determine the fair values included estimating Seghesio Family Vineyards&amp;#x2019; business enterprise value through the use of a discounted cash flow analysis.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Property and equipment asset valuations included an analysis of depreciated replacement cost and current market prices.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company considered several factors to determine the fair value of property and equipment
 including local market conditions
 recent market transactions
 the size
 age
 condition
 utility and character of the property
 the estimated cost to acquire replacement property
 an estimate of depreciation from use and functional obsolescence and the remaining expected useful life of the assets.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Amounts allocated to product inventories were principally based on an analysis of market values on the acquisition date.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;For other components of working capital
 the historical carrying values approximated fair values.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:8pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;

 the amortization period and goodwill were as follows (dollars in thousands):&lt;/font&gt;

			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Base rent expense was &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$26&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;
 &amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$21
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; and &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$19
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; for the years ended December 31
 2013
 2012 and 2011
 respectively.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Estimated supplemental rent payments
 which are based on the market value of harvested grapes
 are presented in the grape and bulk wine purchase commitments below.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt&gt;

			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;The Company has entered into long-term contracts through &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;2024&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; to purchase grapes and bulk wine from certain third party and Seghesio family members who are employees of the Company. Total estimated commitments under these agreements are as follows (in thousands):&lt;/font&gt;

383

 &amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$4
856
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; and &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$3

		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Consolidation policy:&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its subsidiaries
 all of which are wholly-owned.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;All intercompany balances and transactions are eliminated in consolidation.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p&gt;&lt;font size=1&gt; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

  
  
  
  

		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Cost of sales:&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Includes grape
 juice and bulk wine costs
 whether purchased or grown
 crush costs
 winemaking and processing costs
 bottling
 packaging
 warehousing and shipping and handling costs.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;For vineyard produced grapes
 grape costs include annual farming costs and amortization of vineyard development expenditures.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;For wines that age longer than one year
 winemaking and processing costs continue to be incurred and capitalized to the cost of wine
 which can range from &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;3&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; to &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;36&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; months.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p&gt;&lt;font size=1&gt; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

  
  
  
  
  
  
  

		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;div style=width:100%&gt;&lt;table cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 style=border-collapse:collapse;margin-left:0pt;&gt;
			&lt;tr&gt;
				&lt;td valign=top style=width:18.50pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:1.00pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;height:1.00pt;overflow:hidden;font-size:0pt;&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:1pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
				&lt;td valign=top style=width:340.50pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:1.00pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;height:1.00pt;overflow:hidden;font-size:0pt;&gt;
						&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
			&lt;/tr&gt;
			&lt;tr&gt;
				&lt;td valign=top style=width:18.50pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:12.40pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:right;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;11.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
				&lt;td valign=top style=width:340.50pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:12.40pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Debt:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
			&lt;/tr&gt;
		&lt;/table&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;In March 2013
 Crimson entered into a &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$60
000
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; revolving credit facility with American AgCredit
 FLCA
 as agent for the lenders identified in the revolving credit facility
 comprised of a revolving loan facility and a term revolving loan facility
 which together is secured by substantially all of Crimson&amp;#x2019;s assets.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The revolving credit facility is for up to &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$10
000
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; of availability in the aggregate for a &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;five&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; year term
 and the term revolving credit facility is for up to &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$50
000
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; in the aggregate for a &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;fifteen&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; year term.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;All obligations of Crimson under the revolving credit facility are collateralized by certain real property
 including vineyards and certain winery facilities of Crimson
 accounts receivable
 inventory and intangibles.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Covenants include the maintenance of specified debt and equity ratios
 limitations on the incurrence of additional indebtedness
 limitations on dividends and other distributions to shareholders and restrictions on certain mergers
 consolidations and sales of assets.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;In addition to unused line fees ranging from &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;0.25%&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; to &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;0.375%&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;
 rates for the borrowings are priced based on a performance grid tied to certain financial ratios and the London Interbank Offered Rate
 and would have been &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;1.668%&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; to &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;1.973%&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; at December 31
 2013.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The revolving credit facility can be used to fund acquisitions and working capital requirements; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;no&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; amounts have been borrowed under the facility to date.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;font-size:1pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p&gt;&lt;font size=1&gt; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  

		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-style:italic;&gt;Depletion allowances -&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; The Company pays depletion allowances to its distributors based on their sales to their customers.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;These allowances are estimated on a monthly basis by the Company
 and allowances are accrued as a reduction of sales.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Subsequently
 distributors will bill the Company for actual depletions
 which may be different from the Company&amp;#x2019;s estimate.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Any such differences are recognized in sales when the bill is received.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company has historically been able to estimate depletion allowances without any material differences between actual and estimated expense.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p&gt;&lt;font size=1&gt; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

  
  
  

		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;font-size:1pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;div style=width:100%&gt;&lt;table cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 style=border-collapse:collapse;margin-left:0pt;&gt;
			&lt;tr&gt;
				&lt;td valign=top style=width:18.00pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:1.00pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;height:1.00pt;overflow:hidden;font-size:0pt;&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:1pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
				&lt;td valign=top style=width:421.95pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:1.00pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;height:1.00pt;overflow:hidden;font-size:0pt;&gt;
						&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
			&lt;/tr&gt;
			&lt;tr&gt;
				&lt;td valign=top style=width:18.00pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:12.40pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;10.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
				&lt;td valign=top style=width:421.95pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:12.40pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Stockholder&amp;#x2019;s Equity and Equity Incentive Plan:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
			&lt;/tr&gt;
		&lt;/table&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;On February 25
 2013
 Crimson was recapitalized
 authorized shares were increased to &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;150
000
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; common shares
 &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$.01&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; par value
 and Leucadia distributed &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;24
458
368&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; Crimson common shares to Leucadia shareholders.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The financial statements and notes thereto give retroactive effect to the Distribution for all periods presented.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;In addition
 the Company is authorized to issue &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;15
000
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; shares of one or more series of preferred stock; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;no&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; preferred stock has been issued.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;There were &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;no&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; dilutive or complex equity instruments or securities outstanding at any time during the periods presented.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;In February 2013
 the Company adopted the 2013 Omnibus Incentive Plan
 which provides for the granting of up to &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;1
000
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; stock options or other common stock based awards.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The terms of awards that may be granted
 including vesting and performance criteria
 if any
 will be determined by the Company&amp;#x2019;s board of directors.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;No&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; awards have been granted to date.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p&gt;&lt;font size=1&gt; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  

		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-style:italic;&gt;Review of Long-lived Assets for Impairment&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; - For intangible assets with definite lives
 impairment testing is required if conditions exist that indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;For intangible assets with indefinite lives and for goodwill
 impairment testing is required at least annually or more frequently if events or circumstances indicate that these assets might be impaired.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company currently has no intangible assets with indefinite lives.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Substantially all of the Company&amp;#x2019;s goodwill and other intangible assets result from the acquisition of Seghesio Family Vineyards in May 2011.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Amortization of intangible assets is recorded on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of the assets
 which range from &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;7&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; to &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;17&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; years.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company evaluates goodwill for impairment at the end of each year
 and has concluded that goodwill is not impaired.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:8pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;The Company evaluates long-lived assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset or asset group may not be recoverable.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Long-lived assets consist primarily of property and equipment.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Circumstances that might cause the Company to evaluate its long-lived assets for impairment could include a significant decline in the prices of the Company or the industry can charge for its products
 which could be caused by general economic or other factors
 changes in laws or regulations that make it difficult or more costly for the Company to distribute its products to its markets at prices which generate adequate returns
 natural disasters
 significant decrease in demand for the Company&amp;#x2019;s products or significant increase in the costs to manufacture the Company&amp;#x2019;s products.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Recoverability of assets is measured by a comparison of the carrying amount of an asset group to future net cash flows expected to be generated by the asset group.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;If such assets are considered to be impaired
 the impairment to be recognized is measured by the amount by which the carrying amount of the assets exceeds the fair value of the assets.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company groups its long-lived assets with other assets and liabilities at the lowest level for which identifiable cash flows are largely independent of the cash flows of other assets and liabilities (or asset group).&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;This would typically be at the winery level which is described in note 2 above.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company did not recognize any impairment charges associated with long-lived assets during the &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;three&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; year period ended December 31
 2013.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p&gt;&lt;font size=1&gt; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  

		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;font-size:1pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;div style=width:100%&gt;&lt;table cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 style=border-collapse:collapse;margin-left:0pt;&gt;
			&lt;tr&gt;
				&lt;td valign=top style=width:18.50pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:1.00pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;height:1.00pt;overflow:hidden;font-size:0pt;&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:1pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
				&lt;td valign=top style=width:308.80pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:1.00pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;height:1.00pt;overflow:hidden;font-size:0pt;&gt;
						&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
			&lt;/tr&gt;
