					&lt;p style=margin:0pt 34.1pt 1.1pt 0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Current liabilities acquired&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
				&lt;td valign=bottom style=width:05.35pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;height:12.40pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt 0pt 1.1pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;overflow: hidden;font-size:0pt;&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
				&lt;td valign=bottom style=width:06.00pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt solid #000000 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;height:12.40pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;overflow: hidden;font-size:0pt;&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
				&lt;td valign=bottom style=width:48.55pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt solid #000000 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;height:12.40pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;text-align:right; nowrap=nowrap&gt;&lt;div style=float:left&gt;&lt;/div&gt;877&amp;nbsp;
				&lt;/td&gt;
				&lt;td valign=bottom style=width:05.35pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;height:12.40pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt 0pt 1.1pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;overflow: hidden;font-size:0pt;&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
			&lt;/tr&gt;
			&lt;tr&gt;
				&lt;td valign=bottom style=width:474.60pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #FFFFFF;height:12.40pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt 0pt 3.3pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;overflow: hidden;font-size:0pt;&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
				&lt;td valign=bottom style=width:05.35pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #FFFFFF;height:12.40pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt 0pt 3.3pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;overflow: hidden;font-size:0pt;&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
				&lt;td valign=bottom style=width:06.00pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:2pt double #000000 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #FFFFFF;height:12.40pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
				&lt;td valign=bottom style=width:48.55pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:2pt double #000000 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #FFFFFF;height:12.40pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;text-align:right; nowrap=nowrap&gt;&lt;div style=float:left&gt;&lt;/div&gt;86
018&amp;nbsp;
				&lt;/td&gt;
				&lt;td valign=bottom style=width:05.35pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #FFFFFF;height:12.40pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt 0pt 3.3pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;overflow: hidden;font-size:0pt;&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
			&lt;/tr&gt;
		&lt;/table&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p&gt;&lt;font size=1&gt; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

  
  
  
  
  
  
  

		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:1pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;div style=width:100%&gt;&lt;table cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 style=border-collapse:collapse;margin-left:0pt;&gt;
			&lt;tr&gt;
				&lt;td valign=top style=width:18.00pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:1.00pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;height:1.00pt;overflow:hidden;font-size:0pt;&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:1pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
				&lt;td valign=top style=width:355.55pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:1.00pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;height:1.00pt;overflow:hidden;font-size:0pt;&gt;
						&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
			&lt;/tr&gt;
			&lt;tr&gt;
				&lt;td valign=top style=width:18.00pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:12.40pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;3.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
				&lt;td valign=top style=width:355.55pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:12.40pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
						&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Significant Accounting Policies:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
			&lt;/tr&gt;
		&lt;/table&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;(a)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Critical Accounting Estimates: The Company&amp;#x2019;s consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States (&amp;#x201C;GAAP&amp;#x201D;).&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The preparation of these financial statements requires the Company to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts in the financial statements and disclosures of contingent assets and liabilities.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;On an on-going basis
 the Company evaluates all of these estimates and assumptions.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The following areas have been identified as critical accounting estimates because they have the potential to have a significant impact on the Company's financial statements
 and because they are based on assumptions which are used in the accounting records to reflect
 at a specific point in time
 events whose ultimate outcome won&amp;#x2019;t be known until a later date.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Actual results could differ from these estimates.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-style:italic;&gt;Inventory -&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market
 with cost being determined on the first-in
 first-out method.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Costs associated with winemaking
 and other costs associated with the manufacturing of products for resale
 are recorded as inventory.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;In accordance with general practice within the wine industry
 wine inventories are included in current assets
 although a portion of such inventories may be aged for periods longer than one year.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;As required
 the Company reduces the carrying value of inventories that are obsolete or in excess of estimated usage to estimated net realizable value.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company&amp;#x2019;s estimates of net realizable value are based on analyses and assumptions including
 but not limited to
 historical usage
 future demand and market requirements.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Reductions to the carrying value of inventories are recorded in cost of sales.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;If future demand and/or pricing for the Company&amp;#x2019;s products are less than previously estimated
 then the carrying value of the inventories may be required to be reduced
 resulting in additional expense and reduced profitability.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Inventory write-downs of $0
 $50
000 and $51
000 were recorded during 2013
 2012 and 2011
 respectively.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:8pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-style:italic;&gt;Vineyard Development Costs&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; &amp;#x2013; The Company capitalizes internal vineyard development costs when developing new vineyards or replacing or improving existing vineyards.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;These costs consist primarily of the costs of the vines and expenditures related to labor and materials to prepare the land and construct vine trellises.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Amortization of such costs as annual crop costs is recorded on a straight-line basis over the estimated economic useful life of the vineyard
 which can be as long as &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;25&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; years.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;As circumstances warrant
 the Company re-evaluates the recoverability of capitalized costs
 and will record impairment charges if required.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company has not recorded any significant impairment charges for its vineyards during the last &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;three&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; years.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:8pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-style:italic;&gt;Review of Long-lived Assets for Impairment&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; - For intangible assets with definite lives
 impairment testing is required if conditions exist that indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;For intangible assets with indefinite lives and for goodwill
 impairment testing is required at least annually or more frequently if events or circumstances indicate that these assets might be impaired.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company currently has no intangible assets with indefinite lives.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Substantially all of the Company&amp;#x2019;s goodwill and other intangible assets result from the acquisition of Seghesio Family Vineyards in May 2011.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Amortization of intangible assets is recorded on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of the assets
 which range from &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;7&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; to &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;17&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; years.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company evaluates goodwill for impairment at the end of each year
 and has concluded that goodwill is not impaired.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:8pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;The Company evaluates long-lived assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset or asset group may not be recoverable.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Long-lived assets consist primarily of property and equipment.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Circumstances that might cause the Company to evaluate its long-lived assets for impairment could include a significant decline in the prices of the Company or the industry can charge for its products
 which could be caused by general economic or other factors
 changes in laws or regulations that make it difficult or more costly for the Company to distribute its products to its markets at prices which generate adequate returns
 natural disasters
 significant decrease in demand for the Company&amp;#x2019;s products or significant increase in the costs to manufacture the Company&amp;#x2019;s products.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Recoverability of assets is measured by a comparison of the carrying amount of an asset group to future net cash flows expected to be generated by the asset group.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;If such assets are considered to be impaired
 the impairment to be recognized is measured by the amount by which the carrying amount of the assets exceeds the fair value of the assets.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company groups its long-lived assets with other assets and liabilities at the lowest level for which identifiable cash flows are largely independent of the cash flows of other assets and liabilities (or asset group).&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;This would typically be at the winery level which is described in note 2 above.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company did not recognize any impairment charges associated with long-lived assets during the &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;three&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; year period ended December 31
 2013.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:8pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-style:italic;&gt;Depletion allowances -&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; The Company pays depletion allowances to its distributors based on their sales to their customers.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;These allowances are estimated on a monthly basis by the Company
 and allowances are accrued as a reduction of sales.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Subsequently
 distributors will bill the Company for actual depletions
 which may be different from the Company&amp;#x2019;s estimate.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Any such differences are recognized in sales when the bill is received.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company has historically been able to estimate depletion allowances without any material differences between actual and estimated expense.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:8pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;(b)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Consolidation policy:&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its subsidiaries
 all of which are wholly-owned.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;All intercompany balances and transactions are eliminated in consolidation.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:8pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;(c)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Cash and cash equivalents:&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company considers short-term investments
 which have maturities of less than three months at the time of acquisition
 to be cash equivalents.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company had &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;no&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; short-term investments at December 31
 2013 and 2012.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;(d)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Accounts receivable:&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Accounts receivable are reported at net realizable value.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Interest is not accrued on past-due amounts.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Accounts are charged against the allowance to bad debt as they are deemed uncollectible based upon a periodic review of the accounts.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;(e)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Property and equipment:&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Property and equipment are stated at cost and are depreciated using the straight-line method over the related assets estimated useful lives.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Costs of maintenance and repairs are charged to expense as incurred; significant renewals and betterments are capitalized.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Costs incurred developing vineyards are capitalized until the vineyard becomes commercially productive.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;(f)&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Concentrations of risk:&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company sells the majority of its wine through distributors and retailers.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Receivables arising from these sales are not collateralized.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;For the years ended December 31
 2013
 2012 and 2011
 sales to one customer accounted for approximately &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;14%&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;
 &amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;14%&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; and &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;15%&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; of total sales
 respectively.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Amounts due from this customer represented approximately &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;26%&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; and &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;20%&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; of accounts receivable as of December 31
 2013 and 2012
 respectively.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;The Company maintains its cash in bank deposit accounts that
 at times
 may exceed FDIC insurance &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;thresholds.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:8pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;(g)&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Revenue recognition:&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company recognizes revenue from product sales upon shipment or delivery provided that persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists
 which for sales to wholesalers is a purchase order
 the price is fixed
 title has transferred
 collection of resulting receivables is reasonably assured
 there are no customer acceptance requirements
 and there are no remaining significant obligations.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The cost of depletion allowances and price promotions are treated as reductions of revenues and can be reasonably estimated based upon experience.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Revenue from products sold through retail locations
 wine clubs and the Internet is recognized when the product is received by the customer and payment is received
 based on published retail prices and applicable published discounts.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Revenue includes any shipping and handling costs billed to the customer
 and such amounts are not expected to be sufficient to cover actual costs.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:8pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;(h)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Cost of sales:&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Includes grape
 juice and bulk wine costs
 whether purchased or grown
 crush costs
 winemaking and processing costs
 bottling
 packaging
 warehousing and shipping and handling costs.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;For vineyard produced grapes
 grape costs include annual farming costs and amortization of vineyard development expenditures.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;For wines that age longer than one year
 winemaking and processing costs continue to be incurred and capitalized to the cost of wine
 which can range from &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;3&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; to &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;36&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; months.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:8pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;(i)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Taxes not on income:&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Excise taxes are levied by government agencies on the sale of alcoholic beverages
 including wine.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;These taxes are not collected from customers but are instead the responsibility of the Company.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Excise taxes of &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$982
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;
 &amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$836
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; and &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$760
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; in 2013
 2012 and 2011
 respectively
 were recognized as a reduction to wine sales.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Sales taxes that are collected from customers and remitted to governmental agencies are not reflected as revenues.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;(j)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Advertising costs:&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Advertising costs are expensed as incurred and were &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$286
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;
 &amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$81
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; and &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$82
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; for the years ended December&amp;nbsp;31
 2013
 2012 and 2011
 respectively.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;(k)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Income taxes:&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Income taxes are accounted for under the asset and liability method
 which requires the recognition of deferred tax assets and liabilities for the expected future tax consequences of events that have been included in the consolidated financial statements.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Under this method
 deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined based on the differences between the financial statements and the tax basis of assets and liabilities using enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which the differences are expected to reverse.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The effect of a change in tax rates on deferred tax assets and liabilities is recognized in income in the period that includes the enacted date.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Net tax assets are recorded to the extent the Company believes these assets will more likely than not be realized.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;In making such determination
 the Company considers all available positive and negative evidence
 including scheduled reversals of deferred tax liabilities
 projected future taxable income
 tax planning strategies and recent financial results of operations.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Prior to 2013
 the Company had recorded a full valuation allowance related to its net deferred tax asset.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;As of December 31
 2013
 the Company determined it is more likely than not that a portion of the deferred tax asset will be realized in the future
 and therefore reduced the valuation allowance resulting in the recognition o&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;f a net deferred tax asset of &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$2
500
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:8pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Prior to the Distribution
 the Company and its subsidiaries were included in the consolidated federal and certain consolidated or combined state income tax returns of Leucadia.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;However
 the provisions for income taxes in the consolidated statements of operations have been determined on a theoretical separate-return basis.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company does not have any unrecognized tax benefits; however
 if it did the Company would record accrued interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits as income tax expense.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;See Note 13 for more information.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;(l)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Allocation of expenses: For the years ended December 31
 2013
 2012 and 2011
 the consolidated financial statements include amounts billed/(credited) by Leucadia for general corporate insurance of &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;($85
000)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;
 &amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$305
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; and &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$335
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;
 respectively
 and for internal audit procedures related to Leucadia&amp;#x2019;s consolidated audit of internal controls over financial reporting of &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$28
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;
 &amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$13
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; and &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$38
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;
 respectively.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Amounts billed for insurance were determined either by the Company&amp;#x2019;s directly determined share of third-party insurance premiums or
 if an allocation of third-party insurance premiums
 based on the Company&amp;#x2019;s relative revenues and assets as compared to Leucadia&amp;#x2019;s consolidated revenues and consolidated assets.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Costs related to internal audit services were based on actual hours spent and the internal auditors&amp;#x2019; employment and travel costs.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Subsequent to the Distribution
 the Company became responsible for obtaining its own general corporate insurance policies and internal audit services
 which resulted in additional expense as a result of standalone policies and requirements. &lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:8pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;The Company incurred certain new and incremental costs as a standalone public company including director fees and expenses for its new board of directors
 standalone Delaware franchise tax
 standalone insurance policies increased legal and accounting fees for reviews for the Company&amp;#x2019;s publicly filed financial statements
 proxy and other filings and other services.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Such costs totaled approximately &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$1
600
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;during 2013 and the Company estimates these costs to be approximately &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$1
000
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; per year in future years.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;In addition
 the Company entered into an Administrative Services Agreement with Leucadia whereby Leucadia or its subsidiaries was to provide services principally related to the Company&amp;#x2019;s public filings and financial analysis.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The charges for the administrative services was &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$180
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;per year
 and allowed Leucadia to fully recover the costs directly associated with providing the services
 plus out-of-pocket costs and expenses.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Effective August 1
 2013
 Leucadia and the Company agreed to amend the administrative services agreement to reduce the administrative services provided to the Company by Leucadia and correspondingly reduce the monthly fee from &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$15
000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt; to &lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;$4
500&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company began to provide the administrative services that were no longer provided to the Company by Leucadia.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Pursuant to the amendment
 the administrative services agreement terminated in full in February 2014. &lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;font-size:8pt;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;(m)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;font-family:Arial;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Recent accounting pronouncements:&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Effective January 1
 2012
 the Company adopted new Financial Accounting Standards Board (&amp;#x201C;FASB&amp;#x201D;) guidance with respect to the improvement of the comparability of fair value measurements presented and disclosed in financial statements issued in accordance with GAAP and International Financial Reporting Standards.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The amendment includes requirements for measuring fair value and for disclosing information about fair value measurements
 but does not require additional fair value measurements and is not intended to establish valuation standards or affect valuation practices outside of financial reporting.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The guidance did not have any impact on the Company&amp;#x2019;s consolidated financial statements.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt&gt;
			&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;Effective January 1
 2013
 the Company adopted amended Financial Accounting Standards Board guidance for indefinite lived intangible asset impairment testing. The amended guidance allows an entity to assess qualitative factors to determine whether the existence of events and circumstances indicate that it is more likely than not that an indefinite lived intangible asset is impaired. If an entity concludes it is not more likely than not that an indefinite lived intangible asset is impaired
 the entity is not required to take further action. If an entity concludes otherwise
 then the entity would be required to determine the fair value of the indefinite lived intangible asset and compare the fair value with the carrying amount of the indefinite lived intangible asset. The Company was required to adopt this amended guidance for its annual and interim periods beginning January 1
 2013. The adoption of this amended guidance did not have a significant impact on the Company's consolidated financial statements&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=display: inline;&gt;.&lt;/font&gt;
		&lt;/p&gt;
		&lt;p&gt;&lt;font size=1&gt; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

						&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;
				&lt;td valign=bottom style=width:01.56%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #auto;height:1.00pt;padding:0pt;&gt;
					&lt;p style=margin:0pt;line-height:100%;font-family:Times New Roman;height:1.00pt;overflow:hidden;font-size:0pt;&gt;
						&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;
				&lt;/td&gt;

 but not limited to: current tax expense (benefit)
 deferred tax expense (benefit)
 investment tax credits
 government grants
 the benefits of operating loss carryforwards
 tax expense that results from allocating certain tax benefits either directly to contributed capital or to reduce goodwill or other noncurrent intangible assets of an acquired entity
 adjustments of a deferred tax liability or asset for enacted changes in tax laws or rates or a change in the tax status of the entity
 and adjustments of the beginning-of-the-year balances of a valuation allowance because of a change in circumstances that causes a change in judgment about the realizability of the related deferred tax asset in future years.
              
                
              

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    








        
          

        
          
            

 including the following: the total of all deferred tax liabilities

 (b) whose operating results are regularly reviewed by the enterprise's chief operating decision maker to make decisions about resources to be allocated to the segment and assess its performance

 net of accumulated depreciation
 depletion and amortization
 of long-lived physical assets used in the normal conduct of business and not intended for resale. Examples include
 but are not limited to
 land
 buildings
 machinery and equipment
 office equipment
 furniture and fixtures

 -Subparagraph b
 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15
 2009.  This reference is included to help users transition from the previous accounting hierarchy and will be removed from future versions of this taxonomy.
              

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    








        
          

        
          
            

 physical assets used in the normal conduct of business and not intended for resale
 in 'PnYnMnDTnHnMnS' format
 for example
 'P1Y5M13D' represents the reported fact of one year
 five months
 and thirteen days. Examples include
 but not limited to
 land
 buildings
 machinery and equipment
 office equipment
 furniture and fixtures
 and computer equipment.

 net of receivables from officers
 directors
 owners
 and affiliates of the entity which are attributable to the parent. The amount of the economic entity's stockholders' equity attributable to the parent excludes the amount of stockholders' equity which is allocable to that ownership interest in subsidiary equity which is not attributable to the parent (noncontrolling interest
 minority interest). This excludes temporary equity and is sometimes called permanent equity.

/**
 * Rivet Software Inc.
 *
 * @copyright Copyright (c) 2006-2011 Rivet Software
 Inc. All rights reserved.
 * Version 2.4.0.3
 *
 */
var Show = {};
Show.LastAR = null
Show.hideAR = function(){
	Show.LastAR.style.display = 'none';
};
Show.showAR = function ( link
 id
 win ){
	if( Show.LastAR ){
		Show.hideAR();
	}
	var ref = link;
	do {
		ref = ref.nextSibling;
	} while (ref && ref.nodeName != 'TABLE');
	if (!ref || ref.nodeName != 'TABLE') {
		var tmp = win ?
			win.document.getElementById(id) :
			document.getElementById(id);
		if( tmp ){
			ref = tmp.cloneNode(true);
			ref.id = '';
			link.parentNode.appendChild(ref);
		}
	}
	if( ref ){
		ref.style.display = 'block';
		Show.LastAR = ref;
	}
};
Show.toggleNext = function( link ){
	var ref = link;
	do{
		ref = ref.nextSibling;
	}while( ref.nodeName != 'DIV' );
	if( ref.style &&
		ref.style.display &&
		ref.style.display == 'none' ){
		ref.style.display = 'block';
		if( link.textContent ){
			link.textContent = link.textContent.replace( '+'
 '-' );
		}else{
			link.innerText = link.innerText.replace( '+'
 '-' );
		}
	}else{
		ref.style.display = 'none';
		if( link.textContent ){
			link.textContent = link.textContent.replace( '-'
 '+' );
		}else{
			link.innerText = link.innerText.replace( '-'
 '+' );
		}
	}
};

 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15
 2009.  This reference is included to help users transition from the previous accounting hierarchy and will be removed from future versions of this taxonomy.
              

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    





















    
  
      

          

        

      






        
        


        
        


 the Company evaluates all of these estimates and assumptions.&nbsp;&nbsp;The following areas have been identified as critical accounting estimates because they have the potential to have a significant impact on the Company's financial statements
 and because they are based on assumptions which are used in the accounting records to reflect
 at a specific point in time

		
		
	


        
        

 Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market
 with cost being determined on the first-in
 first-out method.&nbsp;&nbsp;Costs associated with winemaking
 and other costs associated with the manufacturing of products for resale
 are recorded as inventory.&nbsp;&nbsp;In accordance with general practice within the wine industry
 wine inventories are included in current assets
 although a portion of such inventories may be aged for periods longer than one year.&nbsp;&nbsp;As required
 the Company reduces the carrying value of inventories that are obsolete or in excess of estimated usage to estimated net realizable value.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#x2019;s estimates of net realizable value are based on analyses and assumptions including
 but not limited to
 historical usage
 future demand and market requirements.&nbsp;&nbsp;Reductions to the carrying value of inventories are recorded in cost of sales.&nbsp;&nbsp;If future demand and/or pricing for the Company&#x2019;s products are less than previously estimated
 then the carrying value of the inventories may be required to be reduced
 resulting in additional expense and reduced profitability.&nbsp;&nbsp;Inventory write-downs of $0
 $50
000 and $51
000 were recorded during 2013
 2012 and 2011

		
		
	


        
        

 &#x2013; The Company capitalizes internal vineyard development costs when developing new vineyards or replacing or improving existing vineyards.&nbsp;&nbsp;These costs consist primarily of the costs of the vines and expenditures related to labor and materials to prepare the land and construct vine trellises.&nbsp;&nbsp;Amortization of such costs as annual crop costs is recorded on a straight-line basis over the estimated economic useful life of the vineyard
 years.&nbsp;&nbsp;As circumstances warrant
 the Company re-evaluates the recoverability of capitalized costs
 and will record impairment charges if required.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has not recorded any significant impairment charges for its vineyards during the last 
		
		
	


        
        

 - For intangible assets with definite lives
 impairment testing is required if conditions exist that indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable.&nbsp;&nbsp;For intangible assets with indefinite lives and for goodwill
 impairment testing is required at least annually or more frequently if events or circumstances indicate that these assets might be impaired.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company currently has no intangible assets with indefinite lives.&nbsp;&nbsp;Substantially all of the Company&#x2019;s goodwill and other intangible assets result from the acquisition of Seghesio Family Vineyards in May 2011.&nbsp;&nbsp;Amortization of intangible assets is recorded on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of the assets
 years.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company evaluates goodwill for impairment at the end of each year

 2012
 the Company adopted new Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#x201C;FASB&#x201D;) guidance with respect to the improvement of the comparability of fair value measurements presented and disclosed in financial statements issued in accordance with GAAP and International Financial Reporting Standards.&nbsp;&nbsp;The amendment includes requirements for measuring fair value and for disclosing information about fair value measurements

		

			
		


 2013
 the Company adopted amended Financial Accounting Standards Board guidance for indefinite lived intangible asset impairment testing. The amended guidance allows an entity to assess qualitative factors to determine whether the existence of events and circumstances indicate that it is more likely than not that an indefinite lived intangible asset is impaired. If an entity concludes it is not more likely than not that an indefinite lived intangible asset is impaired
 the entity is not required to take further action. If an entity concludes otherwise
 then the entity would be required to determine the fair value of the indefinite lived intangible asset and compare the fair value with the carrying amount of the indefinite lived intangible asset. The Company was required to adopt this amended guidance for its annual and interim periods beginning January 1

Critical Accounting Estimates: The Company&#x2019;s consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States (&#x201C;GAAP&#x201D;).&nbsp;&nbsp;The preparation of these financial statements requires the Company to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts in the financial statements and disclosures of contingent assets and liabilities.&nbsp;&nbsp;On an on-going basis
 the Company evaluates all of these estimates and assumptions.&nbsp;&nbsp;The following areas have been identified as critical accounting estimates because they have the potential to have a significant impact on the Company's financial statements
 and because they are based on assumptions which are used in the accounting records to reflect
 at a specific point in time

		

			
		

 Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market
 with cost being determined on the first-in
 first-out method.&nbsp;&nbsp;Costs associated with winemaking
 and other costs associated with the manufacturing of products for resale
 are recorded as inventory.&nbsp;&nbsp;In accordance with general practice within the wine industry
 wine inventories are included in current assets
 although a portion of such inventories may be aged for periods longer than one year.&nbsp;&nbsp;As required
 the Company reduces the carrying value of inventories that are obsolete or in excess of estimated usage to estimated net realizable value.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#x2019;s estimates of net realizable value are based on analyses and assumptions including
 but not limited to
 historical usage
 future demand and market requirements.&nbsp;&nbsp;Reductions to the carrying value of inventories are recorded in cost of sales.&nbsp;&nbsp;If future demand and/or pricing for the Company&#x2019;s products are less than previously estimated
 then the carrying value of the inventories may be required to be reduced
 resulting in additional expense and reduced profitability.&nbsp;&nbsp;Inventory write-downs of $0
 $50
000 and $51
000 were recorded during 2013
 2012 and 2011

		

			
		

 &#x2013; The Company capitalizes internal vineyard development costs when developing new vineyards or replacing or improving existing vineyards.&nbsp;&nbsp;These costs consist primarily of the costs of the vines and expenditures related to labor and materials to prepare the land and construct vine trellises.&nbsp;&nbsp;Amortization of such costs as annual crop costs is recorded on a straight-line basis over the estimated economic useful life of the vineyard
 years.&nbsp;&nbsp;As circumstances warrant
 the Company re-evaluates the recoverability of capitalized costs
 and will record impairment charges if required.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has not recorded any significant impairment charges for its vineyards during the last 
		

			
		

 - For intangible assets with definite lives
 impairment testing is required if conditions exist that indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable.&nbsp;&nbsp;For intangible assets with indefinite lives and for goodwill
 impairment testing is required at least annually or more frequently if events or circumstances indicate that these assets might be impaired.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company currently has no intangible assets with indefinite lives.&nbsp;&nbsp;Substantially all of the Company&#x2019;s goodwill and other intangible assets result from the acquisition of Seghesio Family Vineyards in May 2011.&nbsp;&nbsp;Amortization of intangible assets is recorded on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of the assets
 years.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company evaluates goodwill for impairment at the end of each year

		

			
		


 which could be caused by general economic or other factors
 changes in laws or regulations that make it difficult or more costly for the Company to distribute its products to its markets at prices which generate adequate returns
 natural disasters

		

			
		


 year period ended December 31

		

			
		

 The Company pays depletion allowances to its distributors based on their sales to their customers.&nbsp;&nbsp;These allowances are estimated on a monthly basis by the Company
 and allowances are accrued as a reduction of sales.&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequently
 distributors will bill the Company for actual depletions

		

			
		

Consolidation policy:&nbsp;&nbsp;The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its subsidiaries

		

			
		

Cash and cash equivalents:&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company considers short-term investments
 which have maturities of less than three months at the time of acquisition
 short-term investments at December 31

		

			
		

			
		

			
		

			
		

			
		

Concentrations of risk:&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company sells the majority of its wine through distributors and retailers.&nbsp;&nbsp;Receivables arising from these sales are not collateralized.&nbsp;&nbsp;For the years ended December 31
 2013
 2012 and 2011
 sales to one customer accounted for approximately 
 of total sales
 of accounts receivable as of December 31
 2013 and 2012

		

			
		


 at times
 may exceed FDIC insurance 
		

			
		

Revenue recognition:&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company recognizes revenue from product sales upon shipment or delivery provided that persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists
 which for sales to wholesalers is a purchase order
 the price is fixed
 title has transferred
 collection of resulting receivables is reasonably assured
 there are no customer acceptance requirements
 and there are no remaining significant obligations.&nbsp;&nbsp;The cost of depletion allowances and price promotions are treated as reductions of revenues and can be reasonably estimated based upon experience.&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenue from products sold through retail locations
 wine clubs and the Internet is recognized when the product is received by the customer and payment is received
 based on published retail prices and applicable published discounts.&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenue includes any shipping and handling costs billed to the customer

		

			
		

Cost of sales:&nbsp;&nbsp;Includes grape
 juice and bulk wine costs
 whether purchased or grown
 crush costs
 winemaking and processing costs
 bottling
 packaging
 warehousing and shipping and handling costs.&nbsp;&nbsp;For vineyard produced grapes
 grape costs include annual farming costs and amortization of vineyard development expenditures.&nbsp;&nbsp;For wines that age longer than one year
 winemaking and processing costs continue to be incurred and capitalized to the cost of wine
 which can range from 
		

			
		

Taxes not on income:&nbsp;&nbsp;Excise taxes are levied by government agencies on the sale of alcoholic beverages
$982
000
$836
$760
 in 2013
 2012 and 2011
 respectively

		

			
		

$286
000
$81
$82
 for the years ended December&nbsp;31
 2013
 2012 and 2011

		

			
		

Income taxes:&nbsp;&nbsp;Income taxes are accounted for under the asset and liability method
 which requires the recognition of deferred tax assets and liabilities for the expected future tax consequences of events that have been included in the consolidated financial statements.&nbsp;&nbsp;Under this method

		

			
		


 the Company considers all available positive and negative evidence
 including scheduled reversals of deferred tax liabilities
 projected future taxable income
 tax planning strategies and recent financial results of operations.&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior to 2013
 the Company had recorded a full valuation allowance related to its net deferred tax asset.&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December 31
 2013
 the Company determined it is more likely than not that a portion of the deferred tax asset will be realized in the future
$2
500
000
		

			
		


 the Company and its subsidiaries were included in the consolidated federal and certain consolidated or combined state income tax returns of Leucadia.&nbsp;&nbsp;However
 the provisions for income taxes in the consolidated statements of operations have been determined on a theoretical separate-return basis.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company does not have any unrecognized tax benefits; however

 if an allocation of third-party insurance premiums
 based on the Company&#x2019;s relative revenues and assets as compared to Leucadia&#x2019;s consolidated revenues and consolidated assets.&nbsp;&nbsp;Costs related to internal audit services were based on actual hours spent and the internal auditors&#x2019; employment and travel costs.&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequent to the Distribution
 the Company became responsible for obtaining its own general corporate insurance policies and internal audit services

Recent accounting pronouncements:&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective January 1
 2012
 the Company adopted new Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#x201C;FASB&#x201D;) guidance with respect to the improvement of the comparability of fair value measurements presented and disclosed in financial statements issued in accordance with GAAP and International Financial Reporting Standards.&nbsp;&nbsp;The amendment includes requirements for measuring fair value and for disclosing information about fair value measurements

		

			
		


 2013
 the Company adopted amended Financial Accounting Standards Board guidance for indefinite lived intangible asset impairment testing. The amended guidance allows an entity to assess qualitative factors to determine whether the existence of events and circumstances indicate that it is more likely than not that an indefinite lived intangible asset is impaired. If an entity concludes it is not more likely than not that an indefinite lived intangible asset is impaired
 the entity is not required to take further action. If an entity concludes otherwise
 then the entity would be required to determine the fair value of the indefinite lived intangible asset and compare the fair value with the carrying amount of the indefinite lived intangible asset. The Company was required to adopt this amended guidance for its annual and interim periods beginning January 1
 2013. The adoption of this amended guidance did not have a significant impact on the Company's consolidated financial statements
